body: I have a distinct feeling that part of the reason that Avicus is losing players is because of all the rage being thrown about, and in this midst of this rage is excessive swearing. I remember on an old server I played on, they used to filter words such as 'shit' into a word with a bit of humour. They even translated 'lag' to 'kittens'. If this feature was added in, it might restore some of the children players who decided to quit because of all the rudeness and even some others.
body_tagged: I have a distinct feeling that part of the reason that Avicus is losing players is because of all the rage being thrown about, and in this midst of this rage is excessive swearing. I remember on an old server I played on, they used to filter words such as 'shit' into a word with a bit of humour. They even translated 'lag' to 'kittens'. If this feature was added in, it might restore some of the children players who decided to quit because of all the rudeness and even some others.

replies.body:
No. People will just find a way to bypass it. This happened last time there was a filter. Maybe after someone says "lag" or "hacks" a message is sent to them saying

"Tip: Remember not accuse others of hacks. Use /report instead" or
"Tip: Remember, if it is lagging do not spam 'lag' "

replies.body:
How about instead of censoring, Avicus has one of those things where if you type in a message with a swear word, it doesn't actually send and instead has some message like "Do Not swear in chat"
The same would go for hacks "Do not publicly accuse others of hacks, use /report instead"
Not only is that easier, but it would lessen the infraction rates...
And before you say it, it would also bring up the message if someone tried to avoid this function, example sh it, fu ck
sh1t, and a55 would all not be sent :P
replies.body_tagged:
How about instead of censoring, Avicus has one of those things where if you type in a message with a swear word, it doesn't actually send and instead has some message like "Do Not swear in chat"
The same would go for hacks "Do not publicly accuse others of hacks, use /report instead"
Not only is that easier, but it would lessen the infraction rates...
And before you say it, it would also bring up the message if someone tried to avoid this function, example sh it, fu ck
sh1t, and a55 would all not be sent :P

replies.body:
Well, bypassing it would make your swearing look lame and less offensive. Take this for example,
F.u.< K You!

This would be hard to read and,  I would be laughing so hard that they're such a try hard at swearing. Plus, people would need to retry their swearing at the moment because natural instinct is to type it grammatically correct and, it's hard to break a habit to spell wrong. It would be lengthy and to be honest, I'm sure everyone would rather just play the game.

replies.body:
Saying it in chat isn't fine.  It's offensive to people in game, especially if it is directed.  I'm all for free speech, but when you're in a game online with people that may be younger than you, it's important to consider everyone around you.  

I agree that it's just a game and there's no need to scream it in real life; games just don't make me mad.  I was simply saying that that was a better alternative to saying it in chat.
replies.body_tagged:
Saying it in chat isn't fine.  It's offensive to people in game, especially if it is directed.  I'm all for free speech, but when you're in a game online with people that may be younger than you, it's important to consider everyone around you.  

I agree that it's just a game and there's no need to scream it in real life; games just don't make me mad.  I was simply saying that that was a better alternative to saying it in chat.

I agree that it's just a game and there's no need to scream it in real life; games just don't make me mad.  I was simply saying that that was a better alternative to saying it in chat.

replies.body: We're trying to be inclusive, not restrictive.  We're trying to attract people by keeping things as non-offensive as possible, which at this moment includes not swearing.  To say that, "if some people can't handle a bit of swearing, they shouldn't be playing Minecraft," doesn't make sense.  Minecraft was designed as a game of building and surviving.  Nowhere in the game description was it mentioned that users should be restricted based on offensive language.
replies.body_tagged: We're trying to be inclusive, not restrictive.  We're trying to attract people by keeping things as non-offensive as possible, which at this moment includes not swearing.  To say that, "if some people can't handle a bit of swearing, they shouldn't be playing Minecraft," doesn't make sense.  Minecraft was designed as a game of building and surviving.  Nowhere in the game description was it mentioned that users should be restricted based on offensive language.

reply_to.body: It's a video game, with random people, it shouldn't offend you. Also, if some people can't handle a bit of swearing, they shouldn't be playing Minecraft.
reply_to.body_tagged: It's a video game, with random people, it shouldn't offend you. Also, if some people can't handle a bit of swearing, they shouldn't be playing Minecraft.

replies.body: I'd also like to mention that I swear all the time in real life.  But that is under different circumstances.  All of the people are my age, I don't do it to offend anyone, and I know that everyone around me is okay with it.  But in Minecraft, these conditions can't be evaluated as easily, and it's near impossible on a large server like Avicus.

replies.body:
+1, I see so many people cussing in game ;-; gets really annoying seeing "FUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCCKKKKKKKKKKKKKKK"
 (Yes, it is like that a lot of the times)
But like Zedther said, anyone types and presses the enter button any swear word/inappropriate word(s) then it would not send and then the console would send a private message to the player to watch his language. Would help a LOT.
Until then /report will be the best hope.
